div.p: We propose Minimal Gaugino Mediation as the simplest known solution to the supersymmetric flavor and CP problems. The framework predicts a very minimal structure for the soft parameters at ultra-high energies: gaugino masses are unified and non-vanishing whereas all other soft supersymmetry breaking parameters vanish. We show that this boundary condition naturally arises from a small extra dimension and present a complete model which includes a new extra-dimensional solution to the Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu problem. We briefly discuss the predicted superpartner spectrum as a function of the two parameters of the model. The commonly ignored renormalization group evolution above the GUT scale is crucial to the viability of Minimal Gaugino Mediation but does not introduce new model dependence.

Hidden sectors are an essential ingredient of simple and natural models of supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking. The unifying idea is that SUSY is assumed to be broken in the hidden sector and then communicated to the minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM) by messenger interactions which are flavor blind. This structure results in flavor-universal scalar masses and solves the SUSY flavor problem.

In the context of extra dimensions with branes such hidden sectors are very natural. If â€“ for example â€“ the MSSM and the SUSY breaking sector are confined to two different parallel 3-branes embedded in extra dimensions, then the separation in the extra dimensions forbids direct local couplings between the â€œvisibleâ€ MSSM fields and the hidden sector. However, fields on separated branes can still communicate by exchanging bulk messenger fields. Couplings which arise from such non-local bulk mode exchange are suppressed. For a messenger of mass Mğ‘€italic-MM and brane separation Lğ¿italic-LL the suppression factor is e-Mâ¢Lsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘€ğ¿italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-M italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-ML}, which is the Yukawa propagator of the messenger field exchanged between the two branes.

This suggest a very simple scenario for communicating SUSY breaking to the MSSM which guarantees flavor-universal scalar masses. If all light bulk fields have flavor blind couplings then the soft SUSY breaking parameters generated by exchange of these messengers preserve flavor. Heavy bulk modes may violate flavor maximally but the resulting non-universal contributions to the scalar masses are exponentially suppressed [1].

The two obvious candidates for bulk fields which can communicate SUSY breaking to the Standard Model fields in a flavor-blind way are gravity and the Standard Model gauge fields. Gravity as a bulk messenger (â€œAnomaly Mediationâ€ [1, 2]) leads to a very simple and predictive model which unfortunately predicts negative slepton masses and is therefore ruled out in its simplest and most elegant form.***For models which cure Anomaly Mediation by introducing new fields and interactions see [3]. The alternative, Standard Model gauge fields as messengers (â€œGaugino Mediationâ€), has been proposed recently by D.E. Kaplan, Kribs, and Schmaltz [4] as well as by Chacko, Luty, Nelson, and Ponton [5] and was found to work perfectly. In Gaugino Mediation the MSSM matter fields (quarks, leptons and superpartners) live on a â€œmatter braneâ€, while SUSY breaks on a parallel â€œSUSY breaking braneâ€, and the MSSM gauge superfields live in the bulk. Because the gaugino fields are bulk fields they couple directly to the SUSY breaking and obtain soft masses. The MSSM scalars are separated from SUSY breaking by the distance Lğ¿italic-LL and therefore obtain much smaller masses from non-local loops with high momentum modes of the bulk gauge fields [6, 4]. Thus at the compactification scale the theory matches onto a four-dimensional theory with gaugino masses and negligibly small scalar masses.

Vanishing scalar masses and non-vanishing gaugino masses at a high scale, as in no-scale models [7], is very attractive because evolving the theory to low energies via the renormalization group equation generates flavor-universal and positive soft scalar masses. Consistent electroweak symmetry breaking also requires a Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu term of size comparable to the gaugino masses. Thus a minimal version of Gaugino Mediation has only three high energy parameters

div.p: Here M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} is the common gaugino mass at the unification scale, and Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} is the compactification scale where the higher dimensional theory is matched onto the effective four-dimensional theory. Since we wish to preserve the successful prediction of sin2â¡Î¸wsuperscript2subscriptğœƒğ‘¤TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sin^{2}\theta_{w} from gauge coupling unification in the MSSM we limit Mc>MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}>M_{GUT}.

In Section II of this paper we show that this scenario, which we call â€œMinimal Gaugino Mediationâ€ (MgÌƒM), with only the parameters in Eq.Â (1) works very well phenomenologically. The minimal scenario which we advocate here differs from the more general models in [4, 5] in that we do not introduce soft supersymmetry breaking mass parameters in the Higgs sector of the theory at Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. Radiative electroweak symmetry breaking works automatically in MgÌƒMÂ and determines Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu by fitting to the Zğ‘italic-ZZ mass. Therefore the entire superpartner spectrum of MgÌƒMÂ can be computed via the renormalization group equations in terms of only two free parameters: M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. We will see that the running from Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} to MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsubscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} in the grand unified theory is important for the masses of the lightest superpartners. We find that the Bino is the LSP and a perfect cold dark matter candidate in a large region of the modelsâ€™ parameter space. â€œMinimal Gaugino Mediationâ€ also evades all existing collider bounds without fine-tuning.

In Section III we present a complete and economical model which gives rise to the MgÌƒMÂ boundary condition. The model generates the hierarchy between the Planck scale and the SUSY breaking scale with the extra-dimensional dynamical supersymmetry breaking mechanism of Arkani-Hamed, Hall, Smith, and Weiner [8]. To solve the Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu problem without introducing a Bâ¢Î¼ğµğœ‡italic-B italic-muB\mu problem we propose a new mechanism in which five-dimensional N=1ğ‘1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 supersymmetry relates Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu and the gaugino mass.
In Section IV we briefly explain why MgÌƒMÂ has no SUSY CP problem, estimate the neutralino relic density, and conclude.

In this section we determine the predictions of MgÌƒMÂ for the spectrum of MSSM particles. The input parameters of the model are listed in Eq.Â (1). We use the renormalization group equations (RGEs) of the DRÂ¯Â¯DROVERACCENT:overline ARG:start DR ARG:end\overline{\rm DR} scheme to calculate the soft breaking parameters at the electroweak scale. We first outline our procedure for the running and discuss general features of the evolution. Then we present the spectrum of superparticles and describe how the experimental limits translate into constraints on the parameter space of the model.

To connect the boundary condition of Eq.Â (2) to experiments at the weak scale we first run from Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} to MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsubscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} in the unified theory and then run from MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsubscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} to the weak scale with the RGEs of the MSSM. Gaugino domination, or the no-scale, boundary conditions have been studied extensively in the literature, however only including renormalization below the GUT scaleÂ [9, 10, 11]. Since the renormalization effects above the GUT scale are not discussed very frequently in the literature we describe them in some detail first.

Naively, one might be tempted to argue against calculating renormalization effects above the GUT scale because: i. the running above the GUT scale gives only very small masses because logâ¡(McMGâ¢Uâ¢T)â‰ªlogâ¡(MGâ¢Uâ¢TMwâ¢eâ¢aâ¢k)much-less-thansubscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:much-less-than OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w italic-e italic-a italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:)\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}})\ll\log(\frac{M_{GUT}}{M_{weak}}) and ii. the running of soft masses above the GUT scale is model dependent because the theory above the GUT scale contains new unknown fields and couplings which enter the RGEs and give rise to unknown threshold effects. Both of these arguments are invalid as is easy to see: Argument i. neglects group theory factors. For example, the mass which is generated for the right-handed sleptons from running below the GUT scale is very small because they only couple to hypercharge. Above the GUT scale, sleptons are unified into larger GUT representations and the associated larger multiplicity factors more then compensate for the smaller log. The second argument would apply in general theories with soft masses, but it does not apply to MgÌƒMÂ where (at one loop) all generated soft masses are determined by gauge charges only. To understand this consider a generic one-loop RG equation for scalar soft terms

div.p: Here the first term is determined entirely by the known gauge charges, whereas the second term depends on unknown new fields and couplings. However, in MgÌƒMÂ all soft terms for the scalars are zero at Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. Therefore, the soft masses appearing in the second term are small (loop-suppressed compared to M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}), and it is a good approximation to drop the second term. The only remaining model dependence is in the gauge interactions above the GUT scale. The predictions depend on the choice of unified gauge group, and we present predictions for both Sâ¢Uâ¢(5)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and Sâ¢Oâ¢(10)ğ‘†ğ‘‚10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10). Furthermore, there is also a weak dependence on the running of the unified gauge coupling above the GUT scale. However, even adding as much as three additional adjoints to either theory would change the final scalar masses by at most a few percent.â€ â€ â€ A more detailed discussion of RGEs above the GUT scale can be found in [12]. Finally, note that GUT threshold corrections to the supersymmetry breaking scalar masses vanish in DRÂ¯Â¯DROVERACCENT:overline ARG:start DR ARG:end\overline{\rm DR} so that using the RGEs gives the complete answer.

Even though we perform our renormalization group analysis numerically one can also obtain extremely simple approximate formulae for the soft parameters at the GUT scale as follows. Below the GUT scale we integrate the one-loop RGEsÂ [14] numerically. One loop-running has adequate precision if one uses the one-loop improved Higgs potentialÂ [15, 16]. The dominant correction to the lightest Higgs mass comes from top quark loops below the stop mass threshold. It can be accounted for by adding the term

div.p: In addition, we incorporate the contributions to squark and slepton masses arising from D-terms as described in Ref.Â [10].

After evolving all soft masses to the weak scale we impose the constraints which follow from radiative electroweak symmetry breaking. This determines the weak scale values of both Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu and tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta, and we are left with only two free parameters: M1/2â¢(MGâ¢Uâ¢T)subscriptğ‘€12subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)M_{1/2}(M_{GUT}) and the compactification scale Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. The Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu parameter is multiplicatively renormalized, and it does not enter any RGE at one loop. Therefore, we will quote its value at the weak scale.

Without running above the GUT scale (Mc=MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}=M_{GUT}) the stau is the LSP; however for any compactification scale larger than only 1.5â¢MGâ¢Uâ¢T1.5subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡NUMBER:1.5 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.5M_{GUT} the stau is heavier than the lightest neutralino. Note that the dependence of the stau mass on tc=logâ¡(McMGâ¢Uâ¢T)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:)t_{c}=\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}}) is stronger in Sâ¢Oâ¢(10)ğ‘†ğ‘‚10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) than in Sâ¢Uâ¢(5)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5). This follows from the larger group theoretical factors in Sâ¢Oâ¢(10)ğ‘†ğ‘‚10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) which cause soft masses above the GUT scale to be generated more efficiently.

The allowed parameter space for Sâ¢Uâ¢(5)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and Sâ¢Oâ¢(10)ğ‘†ğ‘‚10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) MgÌƒMÂ models is presented in FigureÂ 2. We find a lower bound on tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c} from requiring that the LSP be neutral. An upper bound on tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c} is not shown on the figure, but as discussed above, flavor violating effects due to massive bulk fields limit tcâ‰²4less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘4italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:4t_{c}\mathrel{\lesssim}4. Furthermore, we find that the Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu parameter in our model is given by Î¼=3/2â¢M1/2ğœ‡32subscriptğ‘€12italic-mu RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu=3/2M_{1/2} to an accuracy of better than 2%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% for all values of tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}. This implies a lower bound Î¼>âˆ¼270fragmentsfragmentssimilar-toğœ‡270italic-mu RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:greater-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end NUMBER:270{{{{\mu\mathrel{\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle% \hfill>$\cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \textstyle\hfill>$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{% \cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}}270 GeV with an associated mild tuning of the Zğ‘italic-ZZ mass.

The contours correspond to tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta of 9, 12, 15, 18, and 21 from left to right. The solid lines are for Sâ¢Uâ¢(5)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5), the dashed ones for Sâ¢Oâ¢(10)ğ‘†ğ‘‚10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10).

div.p: FigureÂ 3 shows the MgÌƒMÂ spectrum as a function of the gaugino mass for the example case of an Sâ¢Uâ¢(5)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) GUT with logâ¡(McMGâ¢Uâ¢T)=2subscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡2OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:2\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}})=2. The qualitative features of the spectrum are generic and do not depend on the choice of grand unified group or compactification scale. The masses of all superpartners and Higgs fields, except for the lightest Higgs, rise linearly with M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. As in minimal supergravity the LSP is a Bino-like neutralino. The right-handed stau is the next-to-LSP. As usual, colored superpartners are heaviest, followed by charginos, neutralinos and Higgses with masses of order Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu. The mass of the lightest Higgs particle increases only logarithmically with M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} through the one-loop improvement of the Higgs potential as described in Eq.Â (9).

FigureÂ 3 also shows contours of constant tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta in the M1/2-tcsubscriptğ‘€12subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}-t_{c} plane. Note that in the allowed region tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta is almost independent of M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}, but it increases with tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}.

Since MgÌƒMÂ has only 2 free parameters, measuring the masses of only two particles is in principle sufficient to determine the input parameters and predict the entire superpartner spectrum. In practice, presumably the Higgs will be the first new particle to be discovered. This is because the MSSM Higgs mass bound of 130Â GeV applies also to the MgÌƒMÂ Higgs which could therefore be discovered (or ruled out) at Run II of the TevatronÂ [18], and might even be seen at LEP 205. The mass of the Higgs would give an estimate of M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. Should M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} be close to 200Â GeV, there is a chance that LEP or the Tevatron will discover the first superpartners. For low enough compactification scales LEP would find the right-handed stau and/or selectron. Independent of the compactification scale the Tevatron could then observe charginos in the tri-lepton channel [19]. For larger M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} we would have to wait for the LHC.

It is exciting that observation of the first superpartner immediately also leads to a first test of the model. This is because the discovery would allow a mass measurement of both the discovered superpartner as well as the LSP mass from the distribution of the missing energy. One could then use the measured masses of the Higgs and Bino to obtain two independent determinations of M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and therefore test the model. Once we know a mass of any of the sleptons we can extract the remaining free parameter â€“ tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}. Note that discovery of just a few of the lightest superpartners would already allow a determination of the GUT gauge group!

In this section we describe a simple model which breaks supersymmetry and yields only gaugino masses at the compactification scale. Our model is complete: it generates exponentially small supersymmetry breaking which is mediated to the gauginos via a higher dimensional operator, and Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu is naturally of the same order as the gaugino masses. The model combines the idea of â€œgaugino mediationâ€ with the supersymmetry breaking mechanism proposed in [8].

To begin we recall the higher dimensional set-up of [4]. The MSSM matter and Higgs fields live on a 3+1 dimensional brane embedded in one extra dimension. Supersymmetry is broken dynamically on a parallel brane which is a distance Lğ¿italic-LL apart from the matter brane (Fig. 4). The MSSM gauge fields and gauginos live in the bulk of the extra dimension. We take this extra dimension to be circular, with radius Rğ‘…italic-RR. In order to preserve the quantitative prediction of sin2â¡Î¸wsuperscript2subscriptğœƒğ‘¤TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sin^{2}\theta_{w} from gauge coupling unification in the four dimensional MSSM, we demand that the compactification scale be higher than the GUT scale, R-1â‰¡Mcâ‰¥MGâ¢Uâ¢Tsuperscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR^{-1}\equiv M_{c}\geq M_{GUT}.Â§Â§Â§A similar constraint on the compactification scale also follows from demanding that the extra-dimensional theory remains perturbative up to the five dimensional Planck scale Mğ‘€italic-MM,Â gGâ¢Uâ¢T2=g522â¢Ï€â¢R<24â¢Ï€5/22â¢Ï€â¢Râ¢Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğºğ‘ˆğ‘‡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘”522ğœ‹ğ‘…24superscriptğœ‹522ğœ‹ğ‘…ğ‘€italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R ARG:end RELOP:less-than FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:24 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M ARG:endg_{GUT}^{2}={g_{5}^{2}\over 2\pi R}<{24\pi^{5/2}\over 2\pi RM}. Using 2â¢Ï€â¢Râ¢M3=MPâ¢lâ¢aâ¢nâ¢câ¢k22ğœ‹ğ‘…superscriptğ‘€3superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘˜2NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2\pi RM^{3}=M_{Planck}^{2} this becomes Râ¢MPâ¢lâ¢aâ¢nâ¢câ¢k<750ğ‘…subscriptğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘˜750italic-R italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:750RM_{Planck}<750.

The MSSM gaugino fields can couple to Xğ‘‹italic-XX directly, giving a gaugino mass

div.p: Here, the factor of the extra-dimensional volume (V=2â¢Ï€â¢Rğ‘‰2ğœ‹ğ‘…italic-V RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-RV=2\pi R for a circle) arises from the wave function normalizations of the four-dimensional gaugino fields Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda. All other soft supersymmetry breaking parameters in the MSSM, such as soft scalar masses Xâ€ â¢Xâ¢Qâ€ â¢Qsuperscriptğ‘‹â€ ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘„â€ ğ‘„italic-X POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-X italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-QX^{\dagger}XQ^{\dagger}Q, are suppressed at short distances by extra-dimensional locality [4]. The low-energy values of these parameters are generated from the renormalization group equations as discussed in the previous section.

It is useful to discuss the exact form of the short-distance suppressions in more detail. In general, there are two possible sources for such terms: direct contact terms suppressed by the cut-off Mğ‘€italic-MM or non-local terms from loops of the light bulk gauge fields. The contact terms are not present in the effective theory below Mğ‘€italic-MM to all orders in the local expansion in inverse powers of Mğ‘€italic-MM because they connect fields at different positions. However, this does not preclude the appearance of terms with coefficients e-Lâ¢Msuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘€italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-L italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-LM} which do not have an expansion in local operators. These operators are expected to be flavor violating and are therefore strongly constrained experimentally [20]. The other source of short-distance scalar masses â€“ loops of bulk gauge fields â€“ leads to finite contributions to the masses which are suppressed by additional powers of the separation Lğ¿italic-LL relative to the gaugino mass (10). However, they are flavor universal because they arise from gauge interactions. As discussed in detail in [4] these contributions are negligible compared to the much larger contributions from the renormalization group evolution.

In the following Subsections we turn to discussing the mechanism of supersymmetry breaking and the origin of the Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu term in the model. Our mechanism for breaking supersymmetry and stabilizing the radius of the extra dimension is taken directly from the elegant paper of Arkani-Hamed et. al. [8]. In the following, we summarize their discussion and apply it to our model. Our solution to the Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu problem is new.

Our mechanism is a trivial modification of [8]. div.p: Thus, for Iğ¼italic-II and Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda of order Mğ‘€italic-MM a radius of the desired size is generated by choosing a relatively small mass for the bulk scalar mÎ¨âˆ¼M/30similar-tosubscriptğ‘šÎ¨ğ‘€30italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-M MULOP:divide NUMBER:30m_{\Psi}\sim M/30.
Minimal Gaugino Mediation is a very compelling and predictive theoretical framework which solves all supersymmetric naturalness problems without fine-tuning.

MgÌƒMÂ solves the supersymmetric flavor problem: At the high scale Mcsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} the scalar masses and A-terms vanish, and therefore the only flavor violation in renormalizable couplings resides in the Yukawa couplings. Gaugino loops generate universal positive scalar masses at low energies. Small non-universalities in the masses arise from the Yukawa interactions, but these contributions do not lead to new flavor violation because they are aligned with the Yukawa matrices. An exception to this is the running of the scalar masses above the GUT scale where flavor is broken by unified interactionsÂ [13, 21]. Since the right-handed sleptons are light in MgÌƒMÂ event rates for lepton flavor violating processes such as Î¼â†’eâ¢Î³â†’ğœ‡ğ‘’ğ›¾italic-mu ARROW:rightarrow italic-e italic-gamma\mu\rightarrow e\gamma might be near the experimental bounds.

MgÌƒMÂ solves the supersymmetric CP problem: This is easy to understand by realizing that at the compactification scale (where m2=A=B=0superscriptğ‘š2ğ´ğµ0italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A RELOP:equals italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m^{2}=A=B=0) the phases in M1/2subscriptğ‘€12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu can be removed by phase redefinitions of the gaugino fields and the Higgs superfields, respectively. Therefore, the theory has no new phases beyond the phases in the Yukawa couplings and no supersymmetric CP violation. This does not solve the strong CP problem however.

MgÌƒMÂ is very predictive and therefore testable: The model has only two free parameters which implies that there are many relations between the masses of the superpartners and Higgses which can be tested experimentally.

MgÌƒMÂ has a great cold dark matter candidate: The LSP of MgÌƒMÂ is almost a pure Bino for most of the parameter space. This makes the calculation of the relic neutralino (Bino) density relatively easy, because in this scenario neutralino annihilations are dominated by the t-channel exchange of the right-handed sleptons. If one ignores the small (but interesting) region of parameter space where the stau and neutralino are degenerate to within 5%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% (and where co-annihilations are importantÂ [22]) the relic neutralino abundance is given by [23]

div.p: This formula is accurate to about 20%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% over the whole parameter space plotted in Figure 2 except for where neutralinos and staus are almost degenerate (a narrow band surrounding the â€œstau LSPâ€ excluded regions). For MgÌƒMÂ Eq.Â (28) yields abundances which generically are cosmologically safe and often lie within the cosmologically interesting regime 0.1<Î©Ï‡â¢h2<0.30.1subscriptÎ©ğœ’superscriptâ„20.3NUMBER:0.1 RELOP:less-than Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.30.1<\Omega_{\chi}h^{2}<0.3 as is evident from Figure 2.

MgÌƒMÂ is theoretically well motivated: Separation of SUSY breaking and the MSSM matter fields onto two different branes naturally gives rise to the Gaugino Mediation boundary condition. If the Higgs fields also live on the MSSM matter brane then all supersymmetry breaking soft Higgs mass parameters vanish, giving MgÌƒM. The model is very economical and unifies. We believe that the model is sufficiently â€œconservativeâ€, successful in solving all the problems of supersymmetry, and elegant that it has a real chance of describing Nature.
